data.thread_title: RE: Eli Lilly spending big again for Car-T - $2.4bn

data.author: glasshalfdrunk
data.content: Eli Lilly has become the latest Big Pharma to buy itself a corner of the in-vivo CAR-T space via the acquisition of Orna Therapeutics for up to $2.4 billion. Massachusetts-based Orna has been using its engineered circular RNA platform to create a pipeline of in vivo CAR-T cell therapies led by ORN-252. Lilly described the CD19-targetting ORN-252 as “clinical trial-ready,” with the goal being to develop the therapy for B cell-driven autoimmune diseases. While Lilly is paying up to $2.4 billion in cash, the pharma didn’t divulge how much of this will be paid upfront and how much will be held back until certain clinical development milestones are hit. Orna’s pipeline is based on combining engineered circular RNA with lipid nanoparticles to generate cell therapies within a patient’s body. “Experiments to date suggest that Orna's circular RNA platform may deliver more durable expression of therapeutic proteins and therefore unlock treatments that are not feasible with current RNA or cell therapy platforms,” Lilly explained in a Feb. 9 release. Today’s deal means Lilly will be the owner of a conveyor belt of in vivo CAR-Ts. The company said this “broad platform” will offer “long-term innovation in genetic medicine and in vivo cell engineering.” The acquisition follows in the footsteps of the likes of Gilead, which bought in vivo CAR-T company Interius BioTherapeutics for $350 million and inked a deal with Pregene worth as much as $1.6 billion.

data.author: HereforHemo
data.content: Coming. To determine a fair buyout price we would use the rNPV (Risk-Adjusted Net Present Value), as this is the gold standard for biotech valuation because it accounts for the fact that a drug might fail its next trial. Given the current progress—Cohort 1 success, DSMB clearance for Cohort 2, and the "Estonian revenue Shortcut"—the risk profile has dropped significantly. 1. The rNPV Calculation Parameters (current) There are three "pillars" of the company. Everyone uses a 15% discount rate (standard for high-growth biotech) and adjust for the Probability of Technical and Regulatory Success (PTRS). There’s the Asset, the Target Market (AML/HSC), the Peak Annual Revenue, the PTRS (Success Prob.)and Estimated Asset Value: HG-CT-1 (CAR-T) $2.5B (US/EU) $650M 25% (Phase I/II) $162.5M CDX Antibody $4.0B (Conditioning) $900M 15% (Pre-clinical) $135.0M CBR Platform $10B+ (Solid/Viral) $1.5B (Licensing) 5% (Early Stage) $75.0M Total Platform rNPV $372.5M (~£295M) As of February 2026, Hemogenyx has approximately 6.04 million shares in issue so thr Conservative Buyout (Asset Value only): £295M / 6.04M shares = £48.84 per share. However, Big Pharma often pays a 30% "Platform Premium" to prevent competitors from owning the tech. This pushes the valuation to ~$480M (£380M) which would equate to a share price of £62.91. But here’s the exciting part. The above only values CBR at $75m. Any progress on this candidate would likely see the price triple. Any progress in getting CDX fast tracked into the clinic would see a substantial rise in the value of the candidate and of most importantly publishing both good safety and efficacy results of the dose escalation of Patient 4 would eliminate all doubt for a pharmaceutical major, it would turn Hemogenyx from a maybe to a must have to dominate the AML landscape. It would immediately turn Hemogenyx into an £800m to £1.2bn company and we’d be looking at an SP closer to £155. Just my thoughts.

data.author: HereforHemo
data.content: Perhaps after ten consecutive posts on someone who has already stated they are leaving the board we can refocus on the company we’re invested in, with a product candidate that could well catapult the share price into triple figures. Just a thought. 1. Proof of "Durability" (The One-Year Mark) The fact that Patient 1 will reach the one-year survival mark on February 24, 2026, is the strongest indicator yet of the therapy's durability. The Baseline: Many experimental AML treatments show initial "blasts" reduction but fail when the cancer returns rapidly. The Milestone: Surviving one year after a CAR-T infusion in a R/R AML setting strongly suggests that the modified T-cells have not only cleared the cancer but may still be providing immunosurveillance or have allowed for a successful "bridge to transplant," which is often the ultimate goal. 2. High Efficacy at the Lowest Dose All three patients from the first cohort being alive is particularly impressive because this was the lowest dose cohort. In Phase 1 "3+3" design trials, the first group receives a sub-therapeutic dose to test for toxicity. The fact that they are seeing early signs of efficacy (with the third patient showing no detectable AML cells post-treatment) at the lowest dose level suggests that the product could be even more potent as they move into the higher dose escalations recently cleared by the DSMB. 3. Safety Profile vs. Competitors CAR-T therapies are notorious for "Cytokine Release Syndrome" (CRS) and neurotoxicity. Clean Safety: So far, the therapy has been well-tolerated across the first cohort with no adverse effects. FLT3 Targeting: HG-CT-1 targets FLT3, a protein found on most AML cells. A major risk with FLT3 targets is that they are also found on healthy blood stem cells. The survival of these patients suggests Hemogenyx may have solved the "off-target" toxicity issue that has sidelined other AML CAR-T programs. With dose escalation it is highly likely HG-CT-1 will be even more efficacious moving to curative in nature. This is best in class status, transformative and undoubtedly in my mind will be designated a breakthrough therapy therefore being fast tracked through the clinic. HG-CT-1 shows all the signs of being a product candidate worth hundreds of millions of dollars if not billions. The question is which major will move first and when.

The best managers are those that are proactive and make changes before changes are required - unfortunately this notion is lost on those without the foresight and patience to match.

data.content: Losta, ill be real, you should get it out of your system now dude. You have this window between right now and whats coming to grief like its 2B2T. I dont know whats coming first, but I know this shiz is about to get real, take your pick: Resumption of trials - Tech transfer started over 6 months ago once thats done? It aint Hemo calling the shots its MDA + Made working together, suddenly 3 per year could be 3 in 1-2 months. Lets see the trolling when its kids, takes a special kind of troll to attack when kids are involved, look forward to seeing who has those stones... Estonia trials - Yep plenty of people totally dismissing it as fake, not real, not going to happen...... Yea I disagree :P CDX - This was never shelved, they worked on it last year and I am surprised no update except for the fact they have so few staff CBR - As above Time and staffing issues, but it was never shelved, an update is 6 months overdue.. Grants - I saw that the House in the US have passed a bill to restore all the pre DOGE cuts to NIH, if this passes we might actually start to see grant money like most other companies in the US got pre cuts. Partners/Funding - Hemo have went deep silent since ASH and JPM, IDK what talks took place but it looks like there has been some sort of positive outcome. Its easy to be flippant and dismissive of Hemogenyx in this lull between "stuff" while we are almost in pre-launch stage, its like last year was a trial run at a gold mine with a sampler deck just proving out the gold, capable of running a few yards an hour. But we needed the big deck, some way of running trials like a professional outfit, either Made+MDA or Estonia or some partner for CBR or CDX, I do not know which but when that changeover happens and we fire up the machine again? We become demonstratable as good if not better than those companies 200m, 300m+ and thats without any deal. If Vlad has signed a deal? Its certainly possible, then £100 per share = 600m mCap, sounds funny, laugh out loud ha ha funny..... Except the reality is HG-CT-1 is unlikely to be sold for less than $1bn at this point, 500m-1b is the range but likely 1b with most of that being milestone payments. Is this ramping/pumping? Or is this calling out the obvious? Hemogenyx has an mCap of sweet FA. It literally is priced like everything has failed, the valuation is so far below other CAR-T companies and oncology pharma that genuine investors tell me they have put off investing as the mCap makes them think there is something wrong. The mCap here is a result of funding not science. So trolls? Seriously fill your boots for now, if we get a deal its game over for you, if we resume trials? I dont believe our current trolls will stoop that low to attack when kids are involved, I sincerly hope not anyway. Have a good day, catch you all tomorrow, this is a oner for me, out and about today.

data.author: BIGBONE
data.content: The US "Shadow" Trading (OTCQX/OTC) ​When people talk about Hemogenyx being "dual listed" in the US, they are usually referring to its presence on the OTC Markets (ticker: HGELF or HOPHF). ​It’s not a "Listing" in the traditional sense: Unlike the NASDAQ or NYSE, the OTC market is a decentralized dealer network. Hemogenyx doesn't have to meet the same grueling requirements as a US-listed company because it uses its LSE compliance to qualify for trading in the US. ​Why it might look "gone": Sometimes, OTC tickers can become "Grey Market" or "Expert Market" only, meaning they are still technically there, but your specific broker might not allow you to buy or sell them. This can give the illusion that the company isn't on an exchange at all.. Expert only then :)

data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: Ofcourse the shorters and traders have made alot of profit from £16 and higher, many of them even had 100s of thousands of warrants and forward sold those. Thats the reason the SP is down at £6.70 from £18, last year there was a 40% discount placing from Singer, they got warrants, we had the many cheap placings with cheap warrants. Then the SP spiked and several months of those all being dumped, like none of this is or has been debated? I am sure they have made millions in profit in the past 6 months, but I am very sure that the science was never top of their concerns. The London market, of which these .... come are polar opposite of the US, the MO here is you forward sell/short, maximise liquidity, hammer the SP, do a placing to close out the selling walk away with profit never taking risk holding long term. This is the model across most stocks. Wait for a spike or volume, sell, bank cash, hand it to the company for discount shares, move on. With the warrants? Forward sell, do placing at break even, close out walk away, if Warrants come good forward sell, convert, close out. Right now? Completely irrelevant that they may have made 100k profit last year, maybe they did, maybe 1m, thats their business, its history. Few months ago we had a prospectus which was necessary for the purpose of clearing those warrants, it made it sound like a huge placing was coming, I am confident that many brokers, dealers, traders etc were hounding Vlad offering lots of money fully expecting him to accept. Back to the good ole days, forward sell, short like fook, maximise the cash stack, close it out with shares in a placing. Guess what, aint happening, looks like Vlad is saying no thanks to these people, TBH if he needed funds the people introduced a few months ago would be willing to go again so I am sure if he needs he will reach out to them. So yea, maybe there are lots of shorters with lots of profits..... so what? Right now there are alot of shorts open and we are in the 12th month of P1 when FROM DIAGNOSIS the expectancy is 2 months or so for supportive care. I am completely confident the likes of Peterhouse are gone. So what if the shorts made profit before, I care about right now, and my holding not theirs and what I know is Shorts have to close, they dont "hedge their bets" on negative news thats just stupid, nobody hold shorts open for months just incase something bad happens, you short hoping to convince Vlad to do a discount placing and hope it happens quick. IG is particularly risky because there the risk to shorting is huge, if I can line up enough people to buy at the same time using limit orders and take out the MMs???? Shorts get auto closed, their losses can be astronomical :-) And more and more people willing to take part, there was an annoying 2k block today, will wait for a day when there is no big blocks in place.... ;-)

data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: The position on IG is the number of shares and not number of people, in theory it could be one person, it is very likely a small number as Jonny says because not only are tehre not that many idiots out there but also to short you need a professional account. IMO most of us are not professional traders, and even if you could qualify be very careful before deciding to do so. Differences? Benifits - You get better rates, better access to tools and support, access to short selling, better leverage, for £1 you might get £4 leverage instead of £2............... Downsides? You lose ZERO balance protection, for me if I use spreadbetting *(to avoid tax) and SP went to 1p I would lose everything in my account, all gone, no monies, sad face. If I was a professional???? I would go negative, I would owe the broker whatever money I am down in the margin call. Going long this would never be more than like double the money in the account at absolute worst case even if I didnt have zero protection but did have low leverage. If I went short without zero protection?????????? Go short with like £2000 that represents like £10 per penny movement, SP goes back to £18 and your down £12k. putting in £10k in a professional account probably lets you short maybe £100 per penny movement. SP back to £18 = £120k loss from just £10, brokers like IG will try and close before then but if they are unable??? Its the shorter who is liable. This is what we are working to repeat. The actual numbers are much bigger however, 22% is somewhere around 60k shares, thats a total of around £600 per penny, either one person or multiple, but lets assume we do move back to £18 and your going to see losses of £700k. Whats going to happen in the coming days? Weeks? God knows, but be aware that those who are short are exposed, they are taking a big risk, they have my complete and utter support to go balls deep. If you can find a share to borrow and short? PLEASE DO! The days of this share being shortable are over, they just dont realise it yet, the TOXIC warrants are gone, those held by MMs and brokers and traders, the get out of jail free tokens have been cashed in. Neither is Vlad returning to brokers for direct placings, no more PeterhouseSpecials, so again, any shorts? Not going to be closed out by discount confetti. So what? Why short? They THOUGHT they would get one of the above, aint happening. Now? Better pray the trials dont go well, because other than that? Anyone short is screwed and there is no way in hell that IG are going to just say "Dont worry about that negative balance, its cool".

data.author: BBB11
data.content: Lostapound. The strongest data is always at the intended commercial dose. If that dose is safe and shows efficacy, that is the point at which JVs and buy ins usually happen, and fast. Big Pharma are not saviours. They are predatory. They move early to block competitors or late when they believe they can dictate terms. They do not overpay out of goodwill. A JV was possible earlier because HEMO needed funding, but it would not have been competitive. Without efficacy at the long term prescribing dose, leverage is weak. Data from patients 4, 5, and 6 changes that equation entirely. We also do not know what conversations Vlad may already have had with Big Pharma, or whether early terms were simply not acceptable. That information is not public. He has made it clear his ambitions for years and billions before. He doesn't want a quick win, he is smart, and will sell for the right money at the right time. Paediatrics is now a major positive. US grant funding has reopened after being shut down under Trump. HEMO is one of the very few companies in Car-T space with paediatrics approved that has not yet benefited from that funding. That is a structural opportunity for a rerate So say this again after we have efficacy data at the assigned, long term dose. Realistically, you will not get the chance to. The raise completed today funds a minimum of six months, and with the warrants exercised, closer to a full year, during which multiple RNS updates are expected if the data continues to land positively. Patient 1 survival of a year on 24th of Feb. Estonia. Patient 4. Peadatric 1. Loads more possible updates on other products within their portfolio. If efficacy fails, yes, it becomes a fire sale... But is that likely? Given the fact that paediatrics was opened after cohort one data strongly suggests that outcome is extremely unlikely. This the part you obviously don't understand. May have missed bits so others can fill in the knowledge gaps but your de-ramping shows a lack of biotech JV knowledge.

data.author: BBB11
data.content: Lostapound. The strongest data is always at the intended commercial dose. If that dose is safe and shows efficacy, that is the point at which JVs and buy ins usually happen, and fast. Big Pharma are not saviours. They are predatory. They move early to block competitors or late when they believe they can dictate terms. They do not overpay out of goodwill. A JV was possible earlier because HEMO needed funding, but it would not have been competitive. Without efficacy at the long term prescribing dose, leverage is weak. Data from patients 4, 5, and 6 changes that equation entirely. We also do not know what conversations Vlad may already have had with Big Pharma, or whether early terms were simply not acceptable. That information is not public. He has made it clear his ambitions for years and billions before. He doesn't want a quick win, he is smart, and will sell for the right money at the right time. Paediatrics is now a major positive. US grant funding has reopened after being shut down under Trump. HEMO is one of the very few companies in Car-T space with paediatrics approved that has not yet benefited from that funding. That is a structural opportunity for a rerate So say this again after we have efficacy data at the assigned, long term dose. Realistically, you will not get the chance to. The raise completed today funds a minimum of six months, and with the warrants exercised, closer to a full year, during which multiple RNS updates are expected if the data continues to land positively. Patient 1 survival of a year on 24th of Feb. Estonia. Patient 4. Peadatric 1. Loads more possible updates on other products within their portfolio. If efficacy fails, yes, it becomes a fire sale... But is that likely? Given the fact that paediatrics was opened after cohort one data strongly suggests that outcome is extremely unlikely. This the part you obviously don't understand. May have missed bits so others can fill in the knowledge gaps but your de-ramping shows a lack of biotech JV knowledge.

data.content: Dr Sander has proven he is able to raise funds on good terms, this was a positive statement from todays announcement. In parallel, management has undertaken a concerted effort to significantly reduce the Company's burn rate. data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: As someone who has for years droned on about shorting I 100% agree, we are at that point now where shorting does not make sense, IMO the vast majority of short action has always been funding related. Be it brokers/traders/MMs who were involved in placings, offering placings, warrant holders etc, basically shorting but with a safety blanket. Its noticable that the board is pretty silent despite the rise in SP, traders and shorters are not brave, they just play the numbers, when Hemo have cash in the bank, are turning away offers of cash from brokers and have shed off the toxic warrants? Its just not a "safe" short. To short now you pretty much have to pray for some bad news in the trial and thats pure gamling. Now? 2.5m in the bank and I am pretty sure the placee would convert warrants again if asked also meaning Vlad has access to an additional 3m without needing a placing, if he wants more in the bank at any point. What now? Estonia / P4 / C1 / CDX / CBR? I dont know and I dont care, Vlad has now the time and money to deliver the science and has thankfully reassured the market RE the cost savings which was blatently obvious but I was getting really sick telling Lostaplot about. Its justa waiting game now, they are NOT going bust, they did NOT need 5.6m in Jan, they ARE funded. Chill and wait, nothing more to say except a huge thank you to those who took part, I am sure there are many many other forums with shareholder who are extremely jealous that Hemogenyx and Dr S have attracted genuine shareholders with deep pockets on such a toxic market, it is a very very rare thing.

data.thread_title: RE: Eli Lilly spending big again for Car-T - $2.4bn

data.author: glasshalfdrunk
data.content: Eli Lilly has become the latest Big Pharma to buy itself a corner of the in-vivo CAR-T space via the acquisition of Orna Therapeutics for up to $2.4 billion. Massachusetts-based Orna has been using its engineered circular RNA platform to create a pipeline of in vivo CAR-T cell therapies led by ORN-252. Lilly described the CD19-targetting ORN-252 as “clinical trial-ready,” with the goal being to develop the therapy for B cell-driven autoimmune diseases. While Lilly is paying up to $2.4 billion in cash, the pharma didn’t divulge how much of this will be paid upfront and how much will be held back until certain clinical development milestones are hit. Orna’s pipeline is based on combining engineered circular RNA with lipid nanoparticles to generate cell therapies within a patient’s body. “Experiments to date suggest that Orna's circular RNA platform may deliver more durable expression of therapeutic proteins and therefore unlock treatments that are not feasible with current RNA or cell therapy platforms,” Lilly explained in a Feb. 9 release. Today’s deal means Lilly will be the owner of a conveyor belt of in vivo CAR-Ts. The company said this “broad platform” will offer “long-term innovation in genetic medicine and in vivo cell engineering.” The acquisition follows in the footsteps of the likes of Gilead, which bought in vivo CAR-T company Interius BioTherapeutics for $350 million and inked a deal with Pregene worth as much as $1.6 billion.
data.thread_title: Eli Lilly spending big again for Car-T - $2.4bn

data.author: HereforHemo
data.content: Coming. To determine a fair buyout price we would use the rNPV (Risk-Adjusted Net Present Value), as this is the gold standard for biotech valuation because it accounts for the fact that a drug might fail its next trial. Given the current progress—Cohort 1 success, DSMB clearance for Cohort 2, and the "Estonian revenue Shortcut"—the risk profile has dropped significantly. 1. The rNPV Calculation Parameters (current) There are three "pillars" of the company. Everyone uses a 15% discount rate (standard for high-growth biotech) and adjust for the Probability of Technical and Regulatory Success (PTRS). There’s the Asset, the Target Market (AML/HSC), the Peak Annual Revenue, the PTRS (Success Prob.)and Estimated Asset Value: HG-CT-1 (CAR-T) $2.5B (US/EU) $650M 25% (Phase I/II) $162.5M CDX Antibody $4.0B (Conditioning) $900M 15% (Pre-clinical) $135.0M CBR Platform $10B+ (Solid/Viral) $1.5B (Licensing) 5% (Early Stage) $75.0M Total Platform rNPV $372.5M (~£295M) As of February 2026, Hemogenyx has approximately 6.04 million shares in issue so thr Conservative Buyout (Asset Value only): £295M / 6.04M shares = £48.84 per share. However, Big Pharma often pays a 30% "Platform Premium" to prevent competitors from owning the tech. This pushes the valuation to ~$480M (£380M) which would equate to a share price of £62.91. But here’s the exciting part. The above only values CBR at $75m. Any progress on this candidate would likely see the price triple. Any progress in getting CDX fast tracked into the clinic would see a substantial rise in the value of the candidate and of most importantly publishing both good safety and efficacy results of the dose escalation of Patient 4 would eliminate all doubt for a pharmaceutical major, it would turn Hemogenyx from a maybe to a must have to dominate the AML landscape. It would immediately turn Hemogenyx into an £800m to £1.2bn company and we’d be looking at an SP closer to £155. Just my thoughts.

data.author: HereforHemo
data.content: Perhaps after ten consecutive posts on someone who has already stated they are leaving the board we can refocus on the company we’re invested in, with a product candidate that could well catapult the share price into triple figures. Just a thought. 1. Proof of "Durability" (The One-Year Mark) The fact that Patient 1 will reach the one-year survival mark on February 24, 2026, is the strongest indicator yet of the therapy's durability. The Baseline: Many experimental AML treatments show initial "blasts" reduction but fail when the cancer returns rapidly. The Milestone: Surviving one year after a CAR-T infusion in a R/R AML setting strongly suggests that the modified T-cells have not only cleared the cancer but may still be providing immunosurveillance or have allowed for a successful "bridge to transplant," which is often the ultimate goal. 2. High Efficacy at the Lowest Dose All three patients from the first cohort being alive is particularly impressive because this was the lowest dose cohort. In Phase 1 "3+3" design trials, the first group receives a sub-therapeutic dose to test for toxicity. The fact that they are seeing early signs of efficacy (with the third patient showing no detectable AML cells post-treatment) at the lowest dose level suggests that the product could be even more potent as they move into the higher dose escalations recently cleared by the DSMB. 3. Safety Profile vs. Competitors CAR-T therapies are notorious for "Cytokine Release Syndrome" (CRS) and neurotoxicity. Clean Safety: So far, the therapy has been well-tolerated across the first cohort with no adverse effects. FLT3 Targeting: HG-CT-1 targets FLT3, a protein found on most AML cells. A major risk with FLT3 targets is that they are also found on healthy blood stem cells. The survival of these patients suggests Hemogenyx may have solved the "off-target" toxicity issue that has sidelined other AML CAR-T programs. With dose escalation it is highly likely HG-CT-1 will be even more efficacious moving to curative in nature. This is best in class status, transformative and undoubtedly in my mind will be designated a breakthrough therapy therefore being fast tracked through the clinic. HG-CT-1 shows all the signs of being a product candidate worth hundreds of millions of dollars if not billions. The question is which major will move first and when.

data.author: Mr-Mojo-Risin
data.content: If you're extremely confident that the future demand for your product is going to significantly grow, doesn't it stand to reason that you  put things in place now to handle this, at the cost of a short-term delay? Rather that, than wait until the demand explodes and you're then left standing there like a plum, holding your nob thinking 'ah, we might want to find a better way to produce this stuff'. And,  by doing so at that point, inflicting even more delay at a time you should be capitalising, leading to greater urgency which brings about higher costs and frustration to all around; patients, shareholders, medical staff. 'Huge mistake' they'd shout, 'should have prepared for this situation' they'd cry. The best managers are those that are proactive and make changes before changes are required - unfortunately this notion is lost on those without the foresight and patience to match.

data.author: PeterBuc
data.content: Waiting for news requires great patience.  It’s 330 days until Christmas Day.  That’s a definite. But who knows when the important HEMO RNS’s will appear?  All we can safely say is, as each day passes we are one day closer. Worrying about timing doesn’t make it happen any quicker so we just chill out and wait for the answer to the question – are we nearly there yet? I understand that the news we are waiting for is market sensitive.  Are they waiting until everything is sorted out i.e. transfer to MADE, Estonia, Big Pharma involvement etc. before communicating with us? It would be nice to have the odd snippet of news when certain aspects are firmly in place. People often say, “It will be ready when it’s ready.”  That never helps but it’s all we’ve got.  It’s good to see the share price heading in the right direction recently.  It should start to recognise the huge impact any good news will have for the company.

data.content: A lot of what people are seeing pushing the price up are automatic trades, not loads of separate retail buyers. Could be our TR1 buying more... Could be someone else more exciting. If short interest really is around 20 percent of Hemo, that’s a risky place to be. Frustrating part is there’s still no clean way to see the true short position. If this continues to Friday, then we will have a very nice week.

data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: Losta, ill be real, you should get it out of your system now dude. You have this window between right now and whats coming to grief like its 2B2T. I dont know whats coming first, but I know this shiz is about to get real, take your pick: Resumption of trials - Tech transfer started over 6 months ago once thats done? It aint Hemo calling the shots its MDA + Made working together, suddenly 3 per year could be 3 in 1-2 months. Lets see the trolling when its kids, takes a special kind of troll to attack when kids are involved, look forward to seeing who has those stones... Estonia trials - Yep plenty of people totally dismissing it as fake, not real, not going to happen...... Yea I disagree :P CDX - This was never shelved, they worked on it last year and I am surprised no update except for the fact they have so few staff CBR - As above Time and staffing issues, but it was never shelved, an update is 6 months overdue.. Grants - I saw that the House in the US have passed a bill to restore all the pre DOGE cuts to NIH, if this passes we might actually start to see grant money like most other companies in the US got pre cuts. Partners/Funding - Hemo have went deep silent since ASH and JPM, IDK what talks took place but it looks like there has been some sort of positive outcome. Its easy to be flippant and dismissive of Hemogenyx in this lull between "stuff" while we are almost in pre-launch stage, its like last year was a trial run at a gold mine with a sampler deck just proving out the gold, capable of running a few yards an hour. But we needed the big deck, some way of running trials like a professional outfit, either Made+MDA or Estonia or some partner for CBR or CDX, I do not know which but when that changeover happens and we fire up the machine again? We become demonstratable as good if not better than those companies 200m, 300m+ and thats without any deal. If Vlad has signed a deal? Its certainly possible, then £100 per share = 600m mCap, sounds funny, laugh out loud ha ha funny..... Except the reality is HG-CT-1 is unlikely to be sold for less than $1bn at this point, 500m-1b is the range but likely 1b with most of that being milestone payments. Is this ramping/pumping? Or is this calling out the obvious? Hemogenyx has an mCap of sweet FA. It literally is priced like everything has failed, the valuation is so far below other CAR-T companies and oncology pharma that genuine investors tell me they have put off investing as the mCap makes them think there is something wrong. The mCap here is a result of funding not science. So trolls? Seriously fill your boots for now, if we get a deal its game over for you, if we resume trials? I dont believe our current trolls will stoop that low to attack when kids are involved, I sincerly hope not anyway. Have a good day, catch you all tomorrow, this is a oner for me, out and about today.

data.author: BIGBONE
data.content: The US "Shadow" Trading (OTCQX/OTC) ​When people talk about Hemogenyx being "dual listed" in the US, they are usually referring to its presence on the OTC Markets (ticker: HGELF or HOPHF). ​It’s not a "Listing" in the traditional sense: Unlike the NASDAQ or NYSE, the OTC market is a decentralized dealer network. Hemogenyx doesn't have to meet the same grueling requirements as a US-listed company because it uses its LSE compliance to qualify for trading in the US. ​Why it might look "gone": Sometimes, OTC tickers can become "Grey Market" or "Expert Market" only, meaning they are still technically there, but your specific broker might not allow you to buy or sell them. This can give the illusion that the company isn't on an exchange at all.. Expert only then :)

data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: Ofcourse the shorters and traders have made alot of profit from £16 and higher, many of them even had 100s of thousands of warrants and forward sold those. Thats the reason the SP is down at £6.70 from £18, last year there was a 40% discount placing from Singer, they got warrants, we had the many cheap placings with cheap warrants. Then the SP spiked and several months of those all being dumped, like none of this is or has been debated? I am sure they have made millions in profit in the past 6 months, but I am very sure that the science was never top of their concerns. The London market, of which these .... come are polar opposite of the US, the MO here is you forward sell/short, maximise liquidity, hammer the SP, do a placing to close out the selling walk away with profit never taking risk holding long term. This is the model across most stocks. Wait for a spike or volume, sell, bank cash, hand it to the company for discount shares, move on. With the warrants? Forward sell, do placing at break even, close out walk away, if Warrants come good forward sell, convert, close out. Right now? Completely irrelevant that they may have made 100k profit last year, maybe they did, maybe 1m, thats their business, its history. Few months ago we had a prospectus which was necessary for the purpose of clearing those warrants, it made it sound like a huge placing was coming, I am confident that many brokers, dealers, traders etc were hounding Vlad offering lots of money fully expecting him to accept. Back to the good ole days, forward sell, short like fook, maximise the cash stack, close it out with shares in a placing. Guess what, aint happening, looks like Vlad is saying no thanks to these people, TBH if he needed funds the people introduced a few months ago would be willing to go again so I am sure if he needs he will reach out to them. So yea, maybe there are lots of shorters with lots of profits..... so what? Right now there are alot of shorts open and we are in the 12th month of P1 when FROM DIAGNOSIS the expectancy is 2 months or so for supportive care. I am completely confident the likes of Peterhouse are gone. So what if the shorts made profit before, I care about right now, and my holding not theirs and what I know is Shorts have to close, they dont "hedge their bets" on negative news thats just stupid, nobody hold shorts open for months just incase something bad happens, you short hoping to convince Vlad to do a discount placing and hope it happens quick. IG is particularly risky because there the risk to shorting is huge, if I can line up enough people to buy at the same time using limit orders and take out the MMs???? Shorts get auto closed, their losses can be astronomical :-) And more and more people willing to take part, there was an annoying 2k block today, will wait for a day when there is no big blocks in place.... ;-)

data.author: JustHereForHemo
data.content: The position on IG is the number of shares and not number of people, in theory it could be one person, it is very likely a small number as Jonny says because not only are tehre not that many idiots out there but also to short you need a professional account. IMO most of us are not professional traders, and even if you could qualify be very careful before deciding to do so. Differences? Benifits - You get better rates, better access to tools and support, access to short selling, better leverage, for £1 you might get £4 leverage instead of £2............... Downsides? You lose ZERO balance protection, for me if I use spreadbetting *(to avoid tax) and SP went to 1p I would lose everything in my account, all gone, no monies, sad face. If I was a professional???? I would go negative, I would owe the broker whatever money I am down in the margin call. Going long this would never be more than like double the money in the account at absolute worst case even if I didnt have zero protection but did have low leverage. If I went short without zero protection?????????? Go short with like £2000 that represents like £10 per penny movement, SP goes back to £18 and your down £12k. putting in £10k in a professional account probably lets you short maybe £100 per penny movement. SP back to £18 = £120k loss from just £10, brokers like IG will try and close before then but if they are unable??? Its the shorter who is liable. This is what we are working to repeat. The actual numbers are much bigger however, 22% is somewhere around 60k shares, thats a total of around £600 per penny, either one person or multiple, but lets assume we do move back to £18 and your going to see losses of £700k. Whats going to happen in the coming days? Weeks? God knows, but be aware that those who are short are exposed, they are taking a big risk, they have my complete and utter support to go balls deep. If you can find a share to borrow and short? PLEASE DO! The days of this share being shortable are over, they just dont realise it yet, the TOXIC warrants are gone, those held by MMs and brokers and traders, the get out of jail free tokens have been cashed in. Neither is Vlad returning to brokers for direct placings, no more PeterhouseSpecials, so again, any shorts? Not going to be closed out by discount confetti. So what? Why short? They THOUGHT they would get one of the above, aint happening. Now? Better pray the trials dont go well, because other than that? Anyone short is screwed and there is no way in hell that IG are going to just say "Dont worry about that negative balance, its cool".
